model_output:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) systems, particularly in their early stages, relied heavily on Knowledge Engineering (KE). Definition and Foundations:
Knowledge Engineering (KE) [1] is the process of designing knowledge-based systems that can solve specific domain problems by emulating human expertise. These systems are defined as knowledge-intensive software capable of performing tasks normally requiring human expertise [1]. The theoretical foundations of KE lie in the creation and management of structured knowledge representations, reasoning mechanisms, and inference engines to enable these systems to mimic human problem-solving abilities. Historical Evolution:
In the 1950s, the concept of AI emerged, but it wasn't until the early 1980s that expert systems (a type of KE system) moved out of research laboratories and became more popular [1]. During this period, they were applied in various fields such as engineering, chemistry, medicine, and industry [1]. The construction process of these expert systems with specialized domain knowledge is referred to as Knowledge Engineering [1]. The importance of KE was further emphasized in the 1990s, where a study showed that it allowed outsiders (non-designers) to investigate and experimentally validate a knowledge engineering exercise [2]. This transparency was particularly notable due to its rarity in AI and knowledge engineering [2]. In recent years, there has been a resurgence of interest in the evaluation of AI systems, including large language models (LLMs), which have shown great promise in being considered AGI [3]. However, insufficient evidence is provided on the evolution of KE definitions specifically for these more modern developments. References:
